On the road he saw a man from Ethiopia [not present-day Ethiopia (Abyssinia), but Nubia in northern Sudan], a eunuch [or court official; royal servants were sometimes made eunuchs (castrated males), especially if they served in the presence of females]. 37.verse: | Philip answered, “If you believe with all your heart, you can.” The officer said, “I believe that Jesus Christ is the Son of God.”|

10.verse: There was a ·follower of Jesus [disciple] in Damascus named Ananias [22:12]. The Lord spoke to Ananias in a vision, “Ananias!” Ananias answered, “Here I am, Lord.”

Find the house of Judas [not either of Jesus’ disciples by that name; Judas was a common name], and ask for a man named Saul from the city of Tarsus [a town in Cilicia, a Roman province in southeastern Asia Minor (present-day Turkey)]. He is there now, praying.

20.verse: ·Soon [Immediately; At once] he began to ·preach about [proclaim] Jesus in the synagogues, saying, “·Jesus [This one; He] is the Son of God.”

21.verse: All the people who heard him were amazed. They said, “·This is [Isn’t this…?] the man who was in Jerusalem ·trying to destroy [raising havoc for; attacking] those who ·trust in [or worship; call on] this name [the name of Jesus; the name represents the person]! He and all ·the other people who lived in his house [his household] ·worshiped the true God [feared God; “God-fearers” were Gentiles who worshiped the one true God of Israel]. He gave much of his money to ·the poor [or the Jewish people; the people] and prayed to God often.

3.verse: ·One afternoon about three o’clock [About the ninth hour of the day], Cornelius clearly saw a vision. An angel of God came to him and said, “Cornelius!”

Some of them went as far as Phoenicia [northwest of Israel on the coast], Cyprus [an island to the west of the coast of Syria], and Antioch [an important city in Syria] telling the message to others, but only to Jews.

22.verse: The church in Jerusalem heard about all of this, so they sent Barnabas [4:36; 9:26–27] to Antioch.

23.verse: Barnabas was a good man, full of the Holy Spirit and full of faith. When he reached Antioch and saw ·how God had blessed the people [the grace of God], he ·was glad [rejoiced]. He ·encouraged [exhorted; urged] all the believers in Antioch always to ·obey [or remain true to] the Lord with ·all their hearts [resolved/resolute hearts], and many people ·became followers of [were added to] the Lord.

24.verse: Barnabas was a good man, full of the Holy Spirit and full of faith. When he reached Antioch and saw ·how God had blessed the people [the grace of God], he ·was glad [rejoiced]. He ·encouraged [exhorted; urged] all the believers in Antioch always to ·obey [or remain true to] the Lord with ·all their hearts [resolved/resolute hearts], and many people ·became followers of [were added to] the Lord.

25.verse: Then Barnabas went to the city of Tarsus [Paul’s hometown in Cilicia; 9:11] to look for Saul,

26.verse: and when he found Saul, he brought him to Antioch. For a whole year Saul and Barnabas met with the church and taught many people there. 27.verse: ·About that time [In those days] some prophets came [down] from Jerusalem to Antioch.

28.verse: One of them, named Agabus [21:10], stood up and spoke ·with the help of [by the power of; through] the Holy Spirit. He said, “A severe famine is coming to the whole ·world [or inhabited world; probably meaning the Roman empire].” (This happened when Claudius [Roman emperor from AD 41–54] ruled.)

30.verse: They ·gathered the money [did this] and ·gave it to Barnabas and Saul, who brought it to the elders in Judea [sent it to the elders through the hand of Barnabas and Saul].

1.verse: Herod Agrippa Hurts the Church - During that same time King Herod [Agrippa I, who lived 10 BC–AD 44; he was the grandson of Herod the Great (Luke 1:5)] ·began to mistreat [laid hands on to harm/do evil to] some who belonged to the church.

4.verse: After Herod ·arrested [seized] Peter, he put him in ·jail [prison] and handed him over to be guarded by ·sixteen [four squads of four] soldiers. Herod planned to bring Peter ·before the people for trial [to the people; an idiom for a public trial] after the Passover Feast.

8.verse: Then the angel told him, “·Get dressed [or Put on your belt] and put on your sandals.” And Peter did. Then the angel said, “·Put on your coat [Wrap your coat/cloak around you] and follow me.”

9.verse: So Peter followed him out, but he did not know if what the angel was doing was real; he thought he might be seeing a vision.

10.verse: They went past the first and second guards and came to the iron gate that ·separated them from [led to] the city. The gate opened by itself for them, and they went through it. When they had walked down one street, the angel suddenly left him.

11.verse: Then Peter ·realized what had happened [came to himself]. He thought, “Now I know that the Lord really sent his angel to me. He rescued me ·from [from the hands of] Herod and from all the things the [Jewish] people thought would happen.”

12.verse: When he ·considered [realized] this, he went to the home of Mary, the mother of John [who was also called] Mark [12:25; 13:5; 15:37; Col. 4:10; 2 Tim. 4:11; Philem. 24; 1 Pet. 5:13]. Many people were gathered there, praying.

13.verse: Peter knocked on the ·outside door [or courtyard gate], and a servant girl named Rhoda came to answer it.

6.verse: Paul Is Called to Macedonia - ·Paul and those with him [They] went through the areas of Phrygia [a region in north central Asia Minor; 18:23] and Galatia [either the Roman province of Galatia or the old kingdom of Galatia in its north] since the Holy Spirit ·did not let them [prohibited them to; either through circumstances or divine revelation] ·preach the Good News [speak the word] in Asia [a Roman province, in present-day Turkey].

7.verse: When they came ·near [or opposite] the country of Mysia [the northwest section of Asia Minor, present-day Turkey], they tried to go into Bithynia [northern Asia Minor further east than Mysia], but the Spirit of Jesus did not let them.

8.verse: So they passed by Mysia and went to Troas [a city in northwest Asia Minor].

9.verse: That night Paul saw in a vision a man from Macedonia [an area across the Aegean Sea in mainland Greece]. The man stood and ·begged [urged; encouraged], “Come over to Macedonia and help us.”

10.verse: After Paul had seen the vision, we [the switch to first person plural (“we”) indicates that the author, Luke, joined them (see also 20:5—21:18; 27:1—28:16)] immediately ·prepared [made plans; attempted] to leave for Macedonia, ·understanding [or convinced] that God had called us to ·tell the Good News [preach the Gospel] to those people.

11.verse: Lydia Becomes a Christian - We ·left [embarked/put out to sea from] Troas and sailed straight to the island of Samothrace [a mountainous island in the north Aegean]. The next day we sailed to Neapolis [city in Macedonia, the first city Paul visited on the continent of Europe].

12.verse: Then we went by land to Philippi, a Roman colony [a town begun by Romans with Roman laws, customs, and privileges] and ·the leading city in that part [or one of the leading cities in that district; or a city in the first district] of Macedonia. We stayed there for several days.

13.verse: On the Sabbath day we went outside the city gate to the river where we ·thought [expected] we would find a special place for prayer [Philippi evidently had no synagogue because of its small Jewish population]. Some women had gathered there, so we sat down and talked with them.

14.verse: One of the listeners was a woman named Lydia from the city of Thyatira [in western Asia Minor] ·whose job was selling [who was a dealer/merchant in] purple cloth [the most expensive type of material]. She was a worshiper of God [a God-fearing Gentile; 10:2], and the Lord opened her ·mind [heart] to pay attention to what Paul was saying.

15.verse: She and ·all the people in her house [her household] were baptized. Then she ·invited us to her home [urged us], saying, “If you ·think I am truly [have judged me to be] ·a believer in [or faithful to] the Lord, then come stay in my house.” And she ·persuaded us [urged us strongly] to stay with her.

16.verse: Paul and Silas in Jail - Once, while we were going to the place for prayer, a ·servant [slave] girl met us. She had a ·special spirit [spirit/demon of divination/prediction; Python spirit; Python was the serpent god that guarded the Delphic oracle; the term came to be used of the ability to predict the future] in her, and she earned a lot of money for her owners by telling fortunes.

19.verse: When the owners of the ·servant [slave] girl saw that their ·source for making money [hope of profit] was gone, they grabbed Paul and Silas and dragged them before the ·city rulers [leaders; authorities] in the marketplace.

20.verse: They brought Paul and Silas to the ·Roman rulers [magistrates] and said, “These men are Jews and are ·making trouble in [disturbing] our city.

22.verse: The crowd joined the attack against them. The ·Roman officers [magistrates] ·tore [stripped off] the clothes of Paul and Silas and ·had [ordered] them beaten with rods [2 Cor. 11:25].

25.verse: About midnight Paul and Silas were praying and singing ·songs [hymns; praise songs] to God as the other prisoners listened.

28.verse: But [with a great/loud voice] Paul shouted, “Don’t hurt yourself! We are all here.”

30.verse: He brought them outside and said, “·Men [Lords; Sirs], what must I do to be saved?”

31.verse: They said to him, “Believe in the Lord Jesus and you will be saved—you and ·all the people in your house [your household].”

32.verse: So ·Paul and Silas [they] told the ·message [word] of the Lord to the jailer and all the people in his ·house [household].

34.verse: After this the jailer took Paul and Silas home and gave them food. He and his ·family [household] ·were very happy [rejoiced; celebrated] because they now believed in God.

35.verse: The next morning, the ·Roman officers [magistrates] sent the police to tell the jailer, “Let these men go free.”

36.verse: The jailer ·said [reported these words] to Paul, “The ·officers [magistrates] have sent an order to let you go free. You can leave now. Go in peace.”

37.verse: But Paul said to ·the police [them], “They beat us in public ·without a trial [uncondemned], even though we are Roman citizens [Roman law stated that citizens could not be beaten without a trial]. And they threw us in ·jail [prison]. Now they want to ·make us go away [get rid of us; throw us out] ·quietly [in secret]. No! Let them come themselves and bring us out.”

1.verse: Paul and Silas in Thessalonica - ·Paul and Silas [They] traveled through Amphipolis and Apollonia and came to Thessalonica [a city on the Via Egnatia, the major road on the northern Aegean coast] where there was a synagogue.

3.verse: He explained and proved that the ·Christ [Messiah; Christ in Greek and Messiah in Hebrew mean “anointed one”] must ·die [suffer] and then rise from the dead [3:18]. He said, “This Jesus I am ·telling you about [proclaiming to you] is the ·Christ [Messiah].”

4.verse: Some of them were ·convinced [persuaded] and joined Paul and Silas, along with many of the Greeks who ·worshiped God [were devout; sometimes called “God-fearers,” these were Gentiles who worshiped the one true God of Israel; 10:2; 13:43] and ·many [not a few] of the important women [13:50].

5.verse: But ·some others [the Jews] became jealous. So they got some evil men ·from the marketplace [or loitering in the streets; from the marketplace rabble], formed a mob, and ·started a riot [put the city in an uproar]. They ran to Jason’s house, looking for ·Paul and Silas [them], wanting to bring them out to the ·people [assembly; crowd].

6.verse: But when they did not find them, they dragged Jason and some other ·believers [brothers] to the ·leaders of the city [city authorities; politarchs]. The people were yelling, “These people have ·made trouble [agitated; stirred up rebellion] everywhere in the world, and now they have come here too!

7.verse: Jason ·is keeping [has welcomed/received/harbored] them in his house. All of them ·do things against [defy; oppose] the ·laws [decrees] of Caesar, saying there is another king, called Jesus.”

8.verse: When the ·people [crowd] and the ·leaders of the city [city authorities; politarchs] heard these things, they ·became very upset [were disturbed].

10.verse: Paul and Silas Go to Berea - That same night the ·believers [brothers] sent Paul and Silas to ·Berea [a Macedonian city to the south] where [upon arriving] they went to the synagogue [of the Jews].

The Bereans ·were eager to hear what Paul and Silas said [eagerly received the word/message] and ·studied [examined] the Scriptures every day to find out if these things were true [to confirm Paul’s teaching was in line with Scripture].

12.verse: So, many of them believed, as well as ·many [not a few] ·important [prominent; socially high-standing] Greek women and men [17:4].

13.verse: But the Jews [who had opposed Paul earlier] in Thessalonica learned that Paul was preaching the word of God in Berea, too. So they came there, ·upsetting [stirring up] the ·people [crowd] and ·making trouble [causing a disturbance].

14.verse: The ·believers [brothers (and sisters)] ·quickly [immediately] sent Paul away to the ·coast [sea], but Silas and Timothy stayed ·in Berea [behind; there].

15.verse: The people ·leading [escorting; accompanying] Paul went with him to Athens [the leading city in Greece]. Then they carried ·a message [instructions; an order] from Paul back to Silas and Timothy for them to ·come to [rejoin] him as soon as they could.

16.verse: Paul Preaches in Athens - While Paul was waiting for ·Silas and Timothy [them] in Athens, ·he [his spirit] was ·troubled [very distressed] because he saw that the city was full of idols.

17.verse: In the synagogue, he ·talked [or argued; reasoned] with the Jews and the ·Greeks who worshiped God [God-fearing Gentiles; pious/devout ones; see 17:4]. He also ·talked [or argued; reasoned] every day with ·people [those who happened to be present] in the ·marketplace [or public square].

18.verse: Some of the Epicurean [who believed the goal of life was pleasure and did not believe the soul survived death] and Stoic philosophers [who believed life should be lived with indifference to pleasure and pain, and did not believe the soul was immortal] ·argued [conversed; debated] with him, saying, “What is this ·babbler [or charlatan; or ignorant show-off; word-scatterer] trying to say?” Others said, “He seems to be telling us about ·some other gods [foreign gods; strange deities],” because Paul was ·telling them [preaching the Good News/Gospel] about Jesus and ·his rising from the dead [the resurrection].

19.verse: They got Paul and took him to ·a meeting of the Areopagus [or the Hill of Ares; or Mars Hill; Ares (Greek name) or Mars (Roman name) was the god of thunder and war; the council of Areopagus was the oldest and most prestigious court for intellectual and moral matters], where they said, “Please explain to us this new idea you have been teaching.

20.verse: [For; Because] The things you are saying ·are new [or sound strange] to us, and we want to know what ·this teaching means [these things mean].”

21.verse: (All the people of Athens and ·those from other countries [foreigners] who lived there spent all their time talking about and listening to the newest ideas.)

22.verse: Then Paul stood ·before the meeting [in the midst] of the Areopagus and said, “·People of Athens [Men, Athenians], I can see you are very religious in ·all things [every way].

23.verse: [For; Because] As I was going through your city, I ·saw [observed closely] the objects you worship. I found an altar that had these words written on it: TO ·A GOD WHO IS NOT KNOWN [AN UNKNOWN GOD]. ·You worship a god that you don’t know, and this is the God I am telling you about [What therefore you worship as unknown, this I proclaim to you]!

25.verse: This God is the One who gives life, breath, and everything else to ·people [all; everyone; Gen. 1:29; 2:7]. He ·does not need any help from them [is not served by human hands]; he has everything he needs.

26.verse: ·God began by making one person, and from him came all the different people [From one, God made every nation of people] ·who live everywhere in the world [or in order to inhabit the whole earth]. God ·decided exactly [determined; or allotted] ·when [or their appointed time in history; or the seasons of their year] and ·where they must live [or the boundaries of their lands].

27.verse: God wanted them to ·look for [seek] him and perhaps ·search all around for [grope for; reach out to; feel their way towards] him and find him, though he is not far from any of us:

28.verse: ‘[For] ·By his power [or In him] we live and move and ·exist [have our being; a quotation from the Cretan philosopher Epimenides, from about 600 BC].’ [As] Some of your own poets have said: ‘For we are his ·children [offspring; a quotation from Aratus, a Stoic philosopher from Cilicia, who lived about 315–240 BC].’

29.verse: Since we are God’s ·children [offspring], you must not think that ·God [the deity; or the divine nature] is like ·something [an image/likeness] ·that people imagine or make [made by human skill and imagination] from gold, silver, or rock.

30.verse: ·In the past, people did not understand God, and he ignored this [or God overlooked such times of ignorance]. But now, God ·tells [commands] all people in the world to ·change their hearts and lives [repent].

31.verse: [Because] God has ·set [fixed; established] a day that he will judge all the world with ·fairness [righteousness], by the man he ·chose [appointed] long ago. And God has ·proved [or given assurance of] this to everyone by raising that man from the dead!”

34.verse: But some of the ·people [men] ·believed Paul [became believers] and joined him. Among those who believed was Dionysius, a member of the Areopagus, a woman named Damaris, and some others.

But Aquila and his wife, Priscilla, had recently moved to Corinth from Italy, because Claudius [Roman emperor from AD 41–54] commanded that all Jews must leave Rome [an edict issued in AD 49 because of rioting, perhaps between Jews and Jewish Christians]. Paul ·went to visit [or came in contact with; or approached] Aquila and Priscilla.

4.verse: Every Sabbath day he ·talked [reasoned; argued] with the Jews and Greeks in the synagogue, trying ·to persuade them to believe in Jesus [to persuade them].

5.verse: Silas and Timothy came from Macedonia [the northern region of Greece] and joined Paul in Corinth. After this, Paul ·spent all his time telling people the Good News [devoted himself to (preaching) the word], ·showing [testifying to] the Jews that Jesus is the Christ [Messiah; 17:3].

6.verse: But they ·would not accept Paul’s teaching [opposed/resisted him] and ·said some evil things [or reviled him; or blasphemed; 13:45]. So he shook off the dust from his clothes [a sign of protest and that he was done with them, leaving them to God’s judgment; 13:51] and said to them, “·If you are not saved, it will be your own fault [Your blood is on your heads]! ·I have done all I can do [or My conscience is clear; I am innocent/pure]! ·After this [From now on], I will go to ·other nations [the Gentiles].”

9.verse: During the night, the Lord told Paul in a vision [10:9–16; 16:9–10]: “Don’t be afraid. ·Continue talking to people [Speak out] and don’t be ·quiet [silent].

10.verse: [For] I am with you, and no one will [lay a hand on you to] ·hurt [or do evil to] you because many of my people are in this city [Deut. 31:6; Josh. 1:5; Is. 41:10; 43:5; Jer. 1:7–9].”

11.verse: Paul stayed there [in Corinth] for a year and a half, teaching God’s word to the people.

12.verse: Paul Is Brought Before Gallio - When Gallio was the ·governor [proconsul; from AD 51 to 52] of Achaia [a Roman province in present-day southern Greece], ·some people [the Jews] ·came together [made a united attack] against Paul and took him to the ·court [tribunal; judgment seat].

13.verse: They said, “This man is ·teaching [persuading] people to worship God in a way that is against our law.”

14.verse: Paul was about to ·say something [open his mouth], but Gallio spoke [to the Jews], saying, “I would [reasonably; justifiably] listen to you [O Jews,] if you were complaining about a crime or some ·wrong [evil wrongdoing; moral evil].

16.verse: And ·Gallio [he] ·made them leave [threw them out of] the ·court [tribunal; judgment seat].

17.verse: Then they [probably Greeks, using the opportunity to vent their dislike for the Jewish population; less likely, the Jews, angry at Sosthenes for losing the case] all grabbed Sosthenes [perhaps the person mentioned in 1 Cor. 1:1], the ·leader [official] of the synagogue, and beat him there before the ·court [tribunal; judgment seat]. But this ·did not bother [was of no concern to; was ignored by] Gallio.

18.verse: Paul Returns to Antioch - Paul stayed with the ·believers [brothers (and sisters)] for many more days. Then he ·left [said farewell] and sailed for Syria, with Priscilla and Aquila. At Cenchrea [a port city east of Corinth] Paul cut off his hair [a ritual sometimes performed when a promise was accomplished; perhaps this was a Nazirite vow; Num. 6:1–21], because he had made a ·promise to God [vow].

19.verse: Then they went to Ephesus [a major city across the Aegean Sea in western Asia Minor], where Paul left ·Priscilla and Aquila [them]. While Paul was there, he went into the synagogue and talked [or argued; reasoned] with the ·people [Jews].

20.verse: When they asked him to stay with them longer, he ·refused [declined].

21.verse: But as he ·left [said farewell], he said, “I will come back to you again if God ·wants me to [wills].” And so he sailed away from Ephesus.

22.verse: When Paul landed at Caesarea [a port city to the west of Jerusalem on the Mediterranean], he went [up] and gave greetings to the ·church in Jerusalem [the church; the Greek does not mention Jerusalem, but going “up” implies the church in Jerusalem; less likely, it could be the church in Caesarea]. After that, Paul went [down] to Antioch [in Syria; the church that sent Paul out].

23.verse: He stayed there for a while and then left and went through the regions of Galatia and Phrygia [regions in north central Asia Minor; 16:6]. ·He traveled from town to town in these regions […traveling from place to place; …passing through sequentially], ·giving strength to [building up; encouraging; 15:41] all the ·followers [disciples].

24.verse: Apollos in Ephesus and Corinth - [Now; Meanwhile] A Jew named Apollos came to Ephesus. He was ·born in the city [a native] of Alexandria and was ·a good speaker [or a learned man] who ·knew the Scriptures well [was powerful/competent in the Scriptures].

25.verse: He had been taught about the ·way [or Way; 9:2] of the Lord and was always ·very excited [enthusiastic; fervent in spirit] when he spoke and taught ·the truth [accurately the things] about Jesus. But the only baptism Apollos knew about was the baptism that John [the Baptist] taught [baptism of repentance before the ministry of Jesus began; Luke 3].

26.verse: Apollos began to speak ·very boldly [confidently; fearlessly] in the synagogue, and when Priscilla and Aquila heard him, they ·took him to their home [or took him aside; received/took him] and ·helped him better understand [explained more accurately/precisely] the ·way [or Way; 9:2] of God.

27.verse: Now Apollos wanted to ·go [cross over] to Achaia [v. 12]. So the ·believers [brothers (and sisters)] ·helped [encouraged] him and wrote a letter to the ·followers [disciples] there, asking them to ·accept [welcome] him. ·When Apollos arrived, he was a great help to those who, by God’s grace, had believed in Jesus [or When Apollos arrived, by God’s grace he was a great help…].

28.verse: [For] He ·argued very strongly with [vigorously refuted] the Jews ·before all the people [in public (debate)], clearly ·proving [or showing] with the Scriptures that Jesus is the ·Christ [Messiah; 17:3; 18:5].

1.verse: Paul in Ephesus - While Apollos was in Corinth, Paul traveled through the interior regions [the mountainous northern route through the interior of Phrygia; 18:23] to Ephesus [a major city in western Asia Minor; 18:23]. There he found some ·followers [disciples]

3.verse: So he asked, “·What kind of baptism did you have [Into what were you baptized]?” They said, “·It was the baptism that John taught [Into John’s baptism].” [These followers of John the Baptist either (1) knew only of John’s ministry but had not heard that Jesus was the Messiah, or less likely, (2) believed in Jesus as Messiah, but had not been baptized in his name to receive the Holy Spirit.]

4.verse: Paul said, “John’s baptism was a baptism of ·changed hearts and lives [repentance; in preparation for the Messiah]. He told people to believe in the one who would come after him, and that one is Jesus.”

7.verse: There were about twelve people in this group.

8.verse: Paul went into the synagogue and spoke out ·boldly [confidently; fearlessly] for three months. He ·talked [reasoned; argued] with the people and persuaded them ·to accept the things he said about [concerning] the kingdom of God.

9.verse: But some of them became ·stubborn [hardened]. They refused to believe and ·said evil things about [slandered; cursed] ·the Way of Jesus [the Way; another name for the Christian movement; 9:2; 18:25; 22:4] before ·all the people [the crowd]. So Paul left them, and taking the ·followers [disciples] with him, he went to the ·school [lecture hall] of a man named Tyrannus. There Paul ·talked [discussed; reasoned; debated] with people every day

10.verse: for two years. Because of his work, ·everyone who lived in [the whole population of] the province of Asia, both Jews and Greeks, heard the word of the Lord.

11.verse: The Sons of Sceva - God ·used Paul to do [through the hands of Paul did] some ·very special [extraordinary] miracles.

12.verse: Some people took ·handkerchiefs [face cloths] and ·clothes [work aprons; or hand towels] ·that Paul had used [that had touched Paul; from his skin] and put them on the sick. When they did this, ·the sick were healed [the diseases left them] and evil spirits ·left [came out of] them.

13.verse: But some ·people also were traveling around and making evil spirits go out of people [traveling/itinerant Jewish exorcists…]. They tried to ·use [invoke; name] the name of the Lord Jesus to force the evil spirits out. They would say, “By the same Jesus that Paul ·talks about [preaches; proclaims], I ·order [command; adjure] you to come out!”

14.verse: Seven sons of Sceva, a ·leading [Jewish chief] priest, were doing this.

15.verse: But one time ·an [the] evil spirit said to them, “I know Jesus, and I ·know about [recognize] Paul, but who are you?”

16.verse: Then the man who had the evil spirit ·jumped on [leaped on; attacked] them. Because he ·was so much stronger than all of them [violently overpowered them], they ran away from the house naked and ·hurt [wounded].

17.verse: All the people [who lived] in Ephesus—Jews and Greeks—learned about this and were filled with fear and ·gave great honor to [praised/magnified the name of] the Lord Jesus.

18.verse: Many of ·the believers [those who now believed] began to confess openly and ·tell all the evil things they had done [disclose their (evil/magical) practices].

19.verse: ·Some [or A significant number] of them who had ·used magic [practiced sorcery/witchcraft] brought their magic ·books [or scrolls] and burned them before everyone. Those books were worth about fifty thousand silver coins [probably drachmas, each worth a day’s wages].

20.verse: ·So in a powerful way [In this way; Thus] the word of the Lord kept spreading and ·growing [or grew strong; prevailed].

21.verse: After these things [had been fulfilled/accomplished], Paul decided [in his spirit; or in the Spirit] to go to Jerusalem, planning to go through Macedonia [northern Greece] and Achaia [southern Greece] and then on to Jerusalem. He said, “After I have been ·to Jerusalem [there], I must also ·visit [see] Rome.”

22.verse: Paul sent Timothy and Erastus, two of his ·helpers [assistants], ahead to Macedonia, but he himself stayed in [the province of] Asia for a while.

23.verse: Trouble in Ephesus - And during [or about; at] that time, there was ·some serious trouble [no small disturbance] in Ephesus about ·the Way of Jesus [the Way; another name for the Christian movement; 9:2; 18:25; 22:4].

24.verse: A man named Demetrius, who worked with silver, made little silver ·models that looked like the temple [shrines; probably reliefs depicting the goddess in her temple] of the goddess Artemis [Greek goddess of fertility, worshiped particularly in Ephesus]. ·Those who did this work [The artisans/craftsmen] made much money [had no little business].

25.verse: ·Demetrius [He] had a meeting with them and ·some others [workers] who did ·the same kind of work [or similar trades]. He told them, “Men, you know that ·we make a lot of money [our wealth/livelihood comes] from this business.

26.verse: But ·look at [you have seen and heard] what this man Paul is doing. He has ·convinced [persuaded] and ·turned away [or led astray] many people, not only in Ephesus, but in almost all of [the province of] Asia! 3.verse: Paul said to ·Ananias [him], “God ·will [or is about to] ·hit [strike] you, too! You ·are like a wall that has been painted white [whitewashed wall!; a wall with many flaws covered only by a coat of paint]. ·You sit [Do you sit…?] there and judge me, using the ·law of Moses [law], but you are telling them to hit me, and that is against the law.”

4.verse: The men standing near Paul said to him, “·You cannot insult [or How dare you insult; Are you insulting…?] God’s high priest like that!”

5.verse: Paul said, “Brothers, I did not know this man was the high priest [perhaps because of poor eyesight (Gal. 4:15; 6:11), or because the high priest was not in his formal vestments, or Paul is speaking ironically]. It is written in the Scriptures, ‘You must not ·curse [speak evil of] a leader of your people [Ex. 22:28].’”

6.verse: Some of the men in the meeting were Sadducees [Jewish religious party with most influence in the Jewish high court (Sanhedrin) and among the Temple leadership; 4:1], and others were Pharisees [religious party that strictly observed OT laws and added traditions; 5:34]. ·Knowing [or Realizing] this, Paul ·shouted [called out] ·to them [in the council/Sanhedrin], “My brothers, I am a Pharisee, ·and my father was a Pharisee [or descended from Pharisees; a son of Pharisees]. I am on trial here because ·I believe that people will rise from the dead [of the hope and the resurrection].”

7.verse: When Paul said this, there was an argument between the Pharisees and the Sadducees, and the ·group [assembly] was divided.

8.verse: ([For] The Sadducees ·do not believe that people will rise from the dead [say there is no resurrection] nor do they believe in angels or spirits. But the Pharisees believe in them all.)

9.verse: So there was a great ·uproar [commotion; outcry]. Some of the ·teachers of the law [scribes], who were Pharisees, stood up and ·argued [protested violently/vehemently], “We find ·nothing wrong [no fault; nothing evil] with this man. ·Maybe [What if…?] an angel or a spirit did speak to him.”

10.verse: The argument was ·beginning to turn into such a fight [becoming so great] that the ·commander [tribune] was afraid they would tear Paul to pieces. So he told the soldiers to go down and take Paul away and ·put him in [bring him to] the ·army building [barracks].

11.verse: The next night the Lord came and stood by Paul. He said, “Be brave [or Don’t be afraid; Rest assured]! [For just as] You have ·told [testified to] people in Jerusalem about me. You must ·do the same [testify to me] in Rome.”

12.verse: In the morning ·some of Paul’s Jewish opponents [the Jews] ·made a plan [entered a conspiracy] to kill Paul, and they took an oath not to eat or drink anything until they had killed him.

13.verse: There were more than forty men who ·made this plan [formed this conspiracy].

14.verse: They went to the ·leading [chief] priests and the elders and said, “We have ·taken [sworn] an oath not to ·eat or drink [taste anything] until we have killed Paul.

15.verse: So [now] this is what we want you [together with the Sanhedrin] to do: Send a message to the ·commander [tribune] to bring Paul out to you as though you want to ·ask him more questions [determine more accurately the facts of his case]. We will be waiting to kill him ·while he is on the way [before he arrives] here.”

16.verse: But ·Paul’s nephew [the son of Paul’s sister] heard about this ·plan [plot; ambush plan] and went to the ·army building [barracks] and told Paul.

17.verse: Then Paul called one of the ·officers [centurions] and said, “Take this young man to the ·commander [tribune]. [For] He has ·a message for him [something to report to him].”

18.verse: So ·the officer [he] brought ·Paul’s nephew [him] to the ·commander [tribune] and said, “The prisoner, Paul, [called me over and] asked me to bring this young man to you. He wants to tell you something.”

19.verse: The ·commander [tribune] took the young man’s hand and led him to a place where they could be alone. He asked, “What do you ·want to tell [have to report to] me?”

20.verse: ·The young man [He] said, “The Jews have ·decided [conspired; agreed] to ask you to bring Paul down to ·their council meeting [the Sanhedrin] tomorrow. They want you to think they are going to ·ask him more questions [inquire more accurately concerning him].

21.verse: But don’t ·believe [be persuaded by] them! [Because] More than forty men are ·hiding and waiting to kill Paul [waiting in ambush for him]. They have all taken an oath not to eat or drink until they have killed him. Now they are [ready,] waiting for you to agree.”

22.verse: [Therefore] The ·commander [tribune] sent the young man away, ordering him, “Don’t tell anyone that you have ·told [revealed to] me ·about their plan [these things].”

23.verse: Paul Is Sent to Caesarea - Then ·the commander [he] called two ·officers [centurions] and said, “Prepare two hundred soldiers, seventy horsemen, and two hundred men with spears to leave for Caesarea at ·nine o’clock tonight [at the third hour of the night; night begins about 6 PM].

24.verse: Get ·some horses [mounts; animals] for Paul to ride so he can be taken to Governor Felix [held office from AD 52–59] safely.”

25.verse: And he wrote a letter ·that said [of this kind; to this effect; possessing this type/pattern]:

26.verse: From Claudius Lysias. To the Most Excellent Governor Felix: Greetings.

27.verse: Some of the Jews had ·taken [seized] this man and ·planned [were about] to kill him. But I learned that he is a Roman citizen, so I went with my soldiers and ·saved [rescued] him.

28.verse: I wanted to know ·why [the charge/reason] they were accusing him, so I brought him before their ·council meeting [Sanhedrin].

29.verse: I ·learned [found; discovered] that the accusation had to do with ·questions [debates; disputed matters] about their own law [the law of Moses], but no charge was worthy of death or ·jail [chains].

30.verse: When I was ·told [informed] that ·some of them were planning to kill Paul [there was a plot against the man], I sent him to you at once. I also ·told [ordered] ·them [his accusers] to tell you what they have against him.

31.verse: So the soldiers ·did what they were told [followed orders] and took Paul and brought him to the city of Antipatris [city 40 miles from Jerusalem and 25 miles from Caesarea] that night.

32.verse: The next day the horsemen ·went [were sent] with ·Paul to Caesarea [him], but the other soldiers went back to the ·army building in Jerusalem [barracks].

33.verse: When ·the horsemen [they] came to Caesarea and ·gave [delivered] the letter to the governor, they turned Paul over to him.

34.verse: The governor read the letter and asked Paul, “What ·area [province] are you from?” When he learned that Paul was from Cilicia [9:11],

35.verse: he said, “I will hear your case when ·those who are against you [your accusers] come here, too.” Then the governor gave orders for Paul to be kept under guard in Herod’s ·palace [headquarters; Praetorium].

1.verse: Paul Is Accused - Five days later Ananias, the high priest [23:1], ·went to the city of Caesarea [came down] with some of the elders and a ·lawyer [orator; one who speaks in court] named Tertullus. They had come to make charges against Paul before the governor.

2.verse: Paul was called into the meeting, and Tertullus began to accuse him, saying, “Most Excellent Felix! Our people enjoy ·much [or a long period of] peace because of you, and many ·wrong things in our country are being made right [or improvements/reforms have been made] through your ·wise help [or foresight].

3.verse: We ·accept [acknowledge] these things always and in every place, ·and we are thankful for them [or …with much gratitude/thanksgiving].

4.verse: But not wanting to ·take any more of your time [detain you; or bore you], I ·beg [encourage; urge] you ·to be kind and [or because you are kind/patient to] listen to our few words.

5.verse: We have found this man to be a ·troublemaker [pest; plague], ·stirring up [or instigating riots among] ·his people [Jews] everywhere in the world. He is a ·leader [ringleader] of the Nazarene ·group [party; faction; sect].

6.verse: Also, he was trying to ·make the Temple unclean [defile/profane/desecrate the Temple], but we ·stopped [or grabbed; arrested] him. |And we wanted to judge him by our own law.

7.verse: But the ·officer [tribune] Lysias came and used much force to take him from us.

8.verse: And Lysias commanded ·those who wanted to accuse Paul [his accusers] to come to you.| By ·asking him questions [cross-examining him] yourself, you can ·decide [learn; come to know] ·if all these things are true [or the nature of our accusations].”

9.verse: The ·others [Jews] ·agreed [or joined in the attack] and said that all of this was true.

10.verse: When the governor ·made a sign [motioned; gestured] for ·Paul [him] to speak, Paul ·said [responded], “I know you have been a judge over this nation for ·a long time [many years]. So I ·am happy to [gladly; confidently] defend myself before you.

11.verse: You can ·learn [find out; verify] for yourself that I went to worship in Jerusalem ·only [no more than] twelve days ago.

12.verse: ·Those who are accusing me [They] did not find me arguing with anyone in the Temple or stirring up the ·people [crowd] in the synagogues or in the city.

13.verse: They cannot prove the ·things they are saying [charges; accusations] against me now.

14.verse: But I will ·tell you this [admit/confess this to you]: I worship the God of our ·ancestors [forefathers; fathers] as a follower of ·the Way of Jesus [the Way; 22:4], which they call a ·sect [faction; cult]. But I believe everything that is ·taught in [or in agreement with; according to] the law of Moses and that is written in the books of the Prophets.

15.verse: I have the same hope in God that they ·have [accept]—the hope that all people, ·good and bad [righteous and unrighteous], will surely be ·raised from the dead [resurrected; the righteous to salvation, the wicked for judgment; Is. 26:19; Dan. 12:2].

16.verse: This is why I always try to ·do what I believe is right [have a clear conscience] before God and people.

17.verse: “After being away from Jerusalem for ·several [many] years, I went back to bring ·money [alms; gifts for the poor] to my ·people [nation; Rom. 15:26; 1 Cor. 16:1; 2 Cor. 8:4; 9:1, 13] and to ·offer sacrifices [present offerings].

18.verse: I was doing this when they found me in the Temple. I ·had finished the cleansing ceremony [or I was ritually pure; 21:20–29] ·and had not made any trouble; no people were gathering around me [with neither crowd nor trouble].

19.verse: But there were some ·people [Jews] from Asia who should be here, standing before you. If ·I have really done anything wrong [they have anything against me], they are the ones who should accuse me.

20.verse: Or ·ask these people here [let these people themselves state] if they found any ·wrong [crime; unrighteousness] in me when I stood before the ·council in Jerusalem [Sanhedrin].

21.verse: But I did shout one thing when I stood before them: ‘·You are judging me [or I am on trial before you] today ·because I believe that people will rise from [or with respect to the issue of the resurrection of] the dead!’”

22.verse: Felix already ·understood much about [knew accurately the facts about] the ·Way of Jesus [Way; 22:4]. He ·stopped the trial [adjourned the hearing] and said, “When ·commander [tribune] Lysias comes ·here [down], I will decide your case.”

23.verse: Felix ·told [ordered] the ·officer [centurion] to keep ·Paul [him] guarded but to give him some freedom and to let his ·friends [own people] ·bring what he needed [meet his needs; serve him].

24.verse: Paul Speaks to Felix and His Wife - After some days Felix came with his wife, Drusilla, who was Jewish, and asked for Paul to be brought to him. He listened to Paul talk about ·believing [faith] in Christ Jesus.

25.verse: But Felix became afraid when Paul spoke about ·living right [righteousness; justice], self-control, and the ·time when God will judge the world [coming judgment]. He said, “·Go away [or That’s enough for] now. When I have ·more time [another opportunity], I will call for you.”

26.verse: At the same time Felix hoped that ·Paul [he] would give him ·some money [or a bribe], so he often sent for Paul and talked with him.

27.verse: But after two years, Felix was ·replaced [succeeded] by Porcius Festus as governor [from AD 59–62]. But Felix had left Paul in prison to please the Jews.

1.verse: Paul Asks to See Caesar - Three days after Festus ·became governor [arrived in the province], he went [up] from Caesarea to Jerusalem.

2.verse: There the ·leading [chief] priests and the important leaders [of the Jews] made charges against Paul before Festus.

3.verse: They ·asked [urged] Festus to do them a favor. They wanted him to send Paul back to Jerusalem, because they ·had a plan [planned an ambush] to kill him on the way.

4.verse: But Festus answered that Paul would be kept in Caesarea and that he himself was returning there soon.

5.verse: He said, “[Therefore,] Some of your ·leaders [authorities] should go with me. They can accuse the man there in Caesarea, if he has really done something wrong.”

6.verse: ·Festus [He] stayed ·in Jerusalem [among them] another eight or ten days and then went ·back [down] to Caesarea. The next day he ·told the soldiers to bring Paul [ordered Paul to be brought] before him. Festus was seated on the ·judge’s seat [tribunal]

7.verse: when Paul came into the room. The ·people [Jews] who had come [down] from Jerusalem stood around him, making serious charges against him, which they could not prove.

8.verse: This is what Paul said to defend himself: “I have done ·nothing wrong [committed no offense/sin/crime] against the law [of the Jews], against the Temple, or against Caesar.”

9.verse: But Festus wanted to ·please [curry favor with; or do a favor for] the ·people [Jews]. So he asked Paul, “·Do you want [or Are you willing] to go [up] to Jerusalem for me to ·judge [try] you there on these charges?”

10.verse: Paul said, “I am standing at Caesar’s ·judgment seat [or court; tribunal] now, where I should be ·judged [tried]. I have done nothing wrong to ·them [the Jews]; you ·know this is true [clearly recognize this].

11.verse: If I have done something wrong and ·the law says I must die [worthy of death], I do not ask to be saved from death. But if these charges are ·not true [baseless], then no one can ·give me [hand me over; or make me a gift; Paul detects Festus’ desire to gain favor with the Jews] to them. I ·want Caesar to hear my case [appeal to Caesar/the emperor; the right of a Roman citizen for a capital offense]!”

12.verse: Festus talked about this with his ·advisers [council]. Then he said, “You have ·asked to see [appealed to] Caesar, so you will go to Caesar!”

13.verse: Paul Before King Agrippa - A few days later King Agrippa [Agrippa II, the Jewish king who ruled parts of Palestine from AD 52 to 92] and Bernice [Agrippa’s sister and probably his lover] came to Caesarea to ·visit [or welcome; pay their respects to] Festus.

14.verse: They stayed there for ·some time [many days], and Festus told the king about Paul’s case. Festus said, “There is a man that Felix left in prison.

15.verse: When I went to Jerusalem, the ·leading [chief] priests and the elders there made charges against him, asking me to ·sentence him to death [sentence/condemn him].

16.verse: But I answered, ‘When a man is accused of a crime, ·Romans do not [it is not a custom for Romans to] hand him over until he has been allowed to face his accusers and defend himself against their charges.’

17.verse: So when these people came here ·to Caesarea for the trial [with me], I did not ·waste time [postpone/delay the case]. The next day I sat on the ·judge’s seat [tribunal] and commanded that the man be brought in.

18.verse: ·They stood up and accused him [The accusers stood up (to speak)], but not of any ·serious crime [evil deeds] as I ·thought they would [expected].

19.verse: The things they ·said [disputed] were about their own ·religion [or superstition] and about a man named Jesus who died. But Paul ·said [claimed] that he is still alive.

20.verse: ·Not knowing [At a loss] how to ·find out about [investigate] these questions, I asked Paul, ‘·Do you want [or Are you willing] to go to Jerusalem and be ·judged [tried] there [concerning these things]?’

21.verse: But he asked to be ·kept in Caesarea [held in custody]. He wants a decision from ·the emperor [or His Majesty; the Revered/August One; A title for Caesar, the ruler of the Roman world, first given to Caesar “Augustus”; here it refers to Nero]. So I ordered that he be held [in custody] until I could send him to Caesar.”

22.verse: Agrippa said to Festus, “I would also like to hear this man myself.” Festus said, “Tomorrow you will hear him.”

23.verse: [Therefore] The next day Agrippa and Bernice ·appeared [entered] with great ·show [pomp; fanfare]. They went into the ·judgment room [audience hall] with the ·army leaders [tribunes] and the important men of ·Caesarea [the city]. Then Festus ·ordered the soldiers [gave the order] to bring Paul in.

24.verse: Festus said, “King Agrippa and all who are ·gathered [or present] here with us, you see this man. ·All the people [The Jewish community; All the multitude of the Jews], here and in Jerusalem, have ·complained to [or petitioned] me about him, shouting that he should not live any longer.

25.verse: But I found ·no reason to order his [he had done nothing deserving] death. But since he ·asked to be judged by Caesar [appealed to the emperor], I decided to send him.

26.verse: But I have nothing definite to write the ·emperor [lord; sovereign] about him. So I have brought him before all of you—especially you, King Agrippa. ·I hope you can question him and give me […so that from this examination, I might have] something to write.

27.verse: [For] I think it is ·foolish [unreasonable] to send a prisoner to Caesar without telling what charges are against him.”

1.verse: Paul Defends Himself - Agrippa said to Paul, “You may now speak for yourself.” Then Paul ·raised [stretched out] his hand and began to defend himself.

2.verse: He said, “King Agrippa, I am very ·blessed [or fortunate] to stand before you and will ·answer [defend myself against] all the charges the Jews make against me.

3.verse: ·You know so much [You especially know; or I am especially blessed because you know] about all the customs and the ·things they argue about [controversies of the Jews], so ·please [I urge/beg you to] listen to me patiently.

4.verse: “All ·my people [the Jews] know about my ·whole life [manner of life from youth], how I lived from the beginning ·in my own country and later [or among my own people and] in Jerusalem.

5.verse: They have known me for a long time. If they ·want [are willing] to, they can ·tell [testify to] you that I ·was a good [lived as a] Pharisee. ·And the Pharisees obey the laws of my tradition more carefully than any other group […the strictest sect/party of our religion].

6.verse: Now I ·am [stand here] on trial because I hope for the promise that God made to our ·ancestors [forefathers; fathers; either the hope of the Messiah or the resurrection from the dead].

7.verse: This is the promise that the twelve tribes of our people hope to receive as they ·serve [or worship] God day and night. My king, ·they [the Jews] have accused me because ·I hope for this same promise [of this hope]!

8.verse: Why do any of you people think it is ·impossible [unbelievable] for God to raise people from the dead?

9.verse: “I, too, thought ·I ought [it was necessary] to do many things against [the name of] Jesus ·from Nazareth [or the Nazarene].

10.verse: And that is what I did in Jerusalem. The ·leading [chief] priests gave me the ·power [authority] to put many of ·God’s people [God’s holy people; the saints] in ·jail [prison], and when they were ·being killed [or condemned to die], I ·agreed it was a good thing [cast my vote against them].

11.verse: In every synagogue, I often punished them and tried to make them ·speak against [blaspheme; curse] Jesus. I was so ·angry [enraged] against them I even went to ·other [or foreign] cities to ·find them and punish [pursue; or persecute] them.

12.verse: “One time the ·leading [chief] priests gave me ·permission [commission] and the ·power [authority] to go to Damascus.

13.verse: On the ·way [road] there, at noon, [O king,] I saw a light from heaven. It was brighter than the sun and ·flashed [shone] all around me and those who were traveling with me.

14.verse: We all fell to the ground. Then I heard a voice speaking to me in the Hebrew language [probably Aramaic, the common language of the people in that area; 21:40], saying, ‘Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me? ·You are only hurting yourself by fighting me [It is hard for you to kick against the goads; Eccl. 12:11; a goad was a sharp instrument to herd cattle].’

15.verse: I said, ‘Who are you, Lord?’ The Lord said, ‘I am Jesus, the one you are persecuting.

16.verse: ·Stand up [Get up and stand on your feet]! This is why I have come [appeared] to you today: I have ·chosen [appointed] you to be my servant and my witness—you will tell people the things that you have seen and the things that I will show you.

17.verse: I will ·keep you safe [rescue you] from your own people and also from the ·Gentiles [nations]. I am sending you to them

18.verse: to open their eyes so that they may turn away from darkness to the light, away from the ·power [or authority] of Satan and to God. ·Then [or …so that] their sins can be forgiven, and they can have a place with those people who have been ·made holy [sanctified] by ·believing [faith] in me.’

19.verse: “[So; Therefore] King Agrippa, after I had this vision from heaven, I ·obeyed [was not disobedient to] it.

20.verse: [Indeed; or On the contrary] I began telling people that they should ·change their hearts and lives and turn to God [repent] and do ·things [works] ·to show they really had changed [worthy of repentance]. I told this first to those in Damascus, then in Jerusalem, and ·in every part [all throughout the countryside] of Judea, and also to ·people everywhere [the Gentiles; the nations].

21.verse: This is why the Jews ·took [seized] me and were trying to kill me in the Temple [courts; 2:46].

22.verse: But God has helped me [from that day until now; until this day], and so I stand here today, ·telling [testifying/witnessing to] all people, small and great, what I have seen. But I am saying only what the prophets and Moses [meaning the whole OT] said would happen—

23.verse: that the ·Christ [Messiah; the promised king and Savior] would ·die [suffer; 3:17; 17:3], and as the first to rise from the dead, he would ·bring [proclaim] light to his own people [the Jews] and to ·the Gentiles [the nations; people everywhere].”

24.verse: Paul Tries to Persuade Agrippa - While Paul was saying these things to defend himself, Festus said loudly, “Paul, you are ·out of your mind [insane]! Too much ·study [learning] has driven you ·crazy [insane; mad]!”

25.verse: Paul said, “Most excellent Festus, I am not crazy. My words are true and ·sensible [sober; rational].

26.verse: [For] ·King Agrippa [The king] knows about these things, and I can speak ·freely [boldly] to him. [For] I ·know [am convinced/persuaded] ·he has heard about all of these things [none of these things were hidden from him], because they did not happen off in a corner.

27.verse: King Agrippa, do you believe ·what the prophets wrote [the prophets]? I know you believe.”

28.verse: King Agrippa said to Paul, “Do you think you can persuade me to become a Christian in such a short time? [or In a short time you will persuade me to become a Christian!]”

29.verse: Paul said, “Whether it is a short or a long time, I pray to God that not only you but every person listening to me today ·would be saved and be [might become] like me—except for these chains I have.”

30.verse: Then ·King Agrippa [the king], ·Governor Festus [the governor], Bernice, and all the people sitting with them stood up

31.verse: and left the room. Talking to each other, they said, “This man has done nothing ·that deserves [worthy of] death or ·imprisonment [chains].”

32.verse: And Agrippa said to Festus, “We could let this man go free, ·but he has [if he had not] ·asked Caesar to hear his case [appealed to Caesar].”

1.verse: Paul Sails for Rome - It was decided that we would sail for Italy. An ·officer [centurion] named Julius, who served in the ·emperor’s army [Imperial/Augustan regiment; a military unit directly under Caesar], ·guarded [took charge of] Paul and some other prisoners.

2.verse: We got on a ship that was from the city of Adramyttium [a seaport on the northwest coast of Asia Minor] and was about to sail to different ports in Asia [a Roman province, in present-day Turkey]. Aristarchus [19:29; 20:4; Col. 4:10; Philem. 24], a man from the city of Thessalonica [17:1] in Macedonia [16:9], went with us.

3.verse: The next day we ·came to [landed at] Sidon [12:20]. Julius was very ·good [kind; considerate] to Paul and gave him freedom to go visit his friends, who took care of his needs.

4.verse: We left Sidon and sailed ·close to [to the north of; under the lee/shelter of] the island of Cyprus [11:19], because the wind was blowing against us.

5.verse: We ·went [sailed] across the sea by Cilicia [6:9; 9:11] and Pamphylia [13:13] and landed at the city of Myra [a significant city on the Andracus River] in Lycia [a province in southeastern Asia Minor].

6.verse: There the ·officer [centurion] found a ship from Alexandria [a major city in Egypt] that was going to Italy, so he put us on it.

7.verse: We sailed slowly for many days. We had a hard time reaching Cnidus [a port on the southwest side of Asia Minor] because the wind was blowing against us, and we could not go any farther. So we sailed ·by the south side [under the shelter/lee] of the island of Crete [a large island off the southern coast of Asia Minor] near Salmone [a promontory on the eastern coast of Crete, present-day Cape Sidero].

8.verse: Sailing past it was hard. Then we came to a place called Fair Havens [a bay on the southern coast of Crete], near the ·city [town] of Lasea [a nearby Cretan city].

9.verse: We had lost much time, and it was now dangerous to sail, because it was already after ·the Day of Cleansing [the Fast; the Day of Atonement; Yom Kippur in Hebrew; Lev. 16; either late September or early October]. So Paul ·warned [advised] them,

10.verse: “Men, I can see there will be ·a lot of trouble [disaster and heavy loss] on this trip. The ship, the cargo, and even our lives may be lost.”

11.verse: But the centurion was more persuaded by the ·captain [pilot] and the owner of the ship than by what Paul said.

12.verse: Since that harbor was not a ·good [suitable; safe] place for the ship to stay for the winter, ·most of the men [the majority] decided that the ship ·should leave [put to sea]. They hoped we could go to Phoenix and stay there for the winter. Phoenix, a ·city [or port; or harbor] on the island of Crete, had a harbor which faced southwest and northwest.

13.verse: The Storm - When a ·good [moderate; gentle] wind began to blow from the south, the men on the ship thought they ·could reach their goal [or had achieved their objective; or had the opportunity they were waiting for]. So they pulled up the anchor, and we sailed very close to the island of Crete.

14.verse: But ·then [not long after this] a ·very strong [violent; hurricane-like] wind named the “northeaster” came from ·the island [it].

15.verse: The ship was caught in it and could not sail against it. So we stopped trying and ·let the wind carry us [were driven along].

16.verse: When we went ·below [under the lee/shelter of] a small island named Cauda [23 miles off the south coast of Crete], we were barely able to bring in the lifeboat.

17.verse: After the men took the lifeboat in, they tied ·ropes [or cables] ·around [or under] the ship to hold it together. The men were afraid that the ship would ·hit [run aground on] the sandbanks of Syrtis [off the coast of North Africa], so they lowered the ·sail [or sea anchor; gear] and let the wind carry the ship.

18.verse: The next day the storm was blowing us so hard that the men threw out some of the cargo.

19.verse: ·A day later [On the third day] with their own hands they threw out the ship’s ·equipment [rigging; tackle; gear].

20.verse: When we could not see the sun or the stars for many days, and ·the storm was very bad [no small storm raged], we lost all hope of being saved.

21.verse: After ·the men [many] had ·gone without food [or lost their appetite] for a long time, Paul stood up before them and said, “Men, you should have ·listened to me [obeyed me; taken my advice]. You should not have sailed from Crete. Then you would not have all this trouble and loss.

22.verse: But now I ·tell [urge; advise] you to ·cheer up [keep up your courage] because none of you will ·die [be lost]. Only the ship will be lost.

23.verse: ·Last [This] night an angel ·came to [stood by] me from the God I belong to and worship.

24.verse: The angel said, ‘Paul, do not be afraid. You must stand before Caesar. And God has ·promised you that he will save the lives of [graciously granted safety to] everyone sailing with you.’

25.verse: So men, have courage. [For] I trust in God that everything will happen as ·his angel told me [I have been told].

26.verse: But we will ·crash [run aground] on ·an [some/a certain] island.”

27.verse: On the fourteenth night we were still ·being carried [drifting; or being driven] around in the Adriatic Sea [the sea between Greece and Italy including the central Mediterranean]. About ·midnight [the middle of the night] the sailors thought we were close to land,

28.verse: so they ·lowered a rope with a weight on the end of it into the water [took a sounding]. They found that the water was one hundred twenty feet deep [twenty fathoms]. They went a little farther and ·lowered the rope again [took a sounding]. It was ninety feet [fifteen fathoms] deep.

29.verse: ·The sailors [They] were afraid that we would ·hit the rocks [run aground], so they threw four anchors ·into the water [from the stern] and prayed for daylight to come.

30.verse: Some of the sailors wanted to leave the ship, and they lowered the lifeboat, pretending they were throwing more anchors from the ·front of the ship [bow].

31.verse: But Paul told the ·officer [centurion] and the other soldiers, “If these men do not stay in the ship, your lives cannot be saved.”

32.verse: So the soldiers cut the ropes and let the lifeboat fall into the water.

33.verse: Just before dawn Paul ·began persuading [begged; encouraged; urged] all the people to ·eat something [take food]. He said, “·For the past fourteen days [Today is the fourteenth day] you have been ·waiting and watching [in suspense] and ·not eating [going without food, taking nothing].

34.verse: Now I ·beg [urge; encourage] you to ·eat something [take food]. You need it to ·stay alive [survive]. None of you will lose even one hair off your heads.”

35.verse: After he said this, Paul took some bread and thanked God for it before all of them. He broke off a piece and began eating [reflecting language associated with the Lord’s Supper].

36.verse: They all felt ·better [encouraged] and ·started eating [took bread], too.

37.verse: ·There were [We were in all] two hundred seventy-six people on the ship.

38.verse: When they had eaten all they wanted, they began making the ship lighter by throwing the ·grain [wheat] into the sea.

39.verse: The Ship Is Destroyed - When daylight came, they did not recognize the land, but they saw a bay with a beach and wanted to sail the ship ·to [up on] the beach if they could.

40.verse: So they ·cut the ropes to [cast off] the anchors and left ·the anchors [them] in the sea. At the same time, they untied the ropes that were holding the rudders. Then they raised the front sail into the wind and sailed toward the beach.

41.verse: But the ship hit a ·sandbank [reef; shoal; or cross-current; place of two seas]. The front of the ship stuck there and could not move, but the ·back of the ship [stern] began to break up from the big waves.

42.verse: The soldiers ·decided [made a decision] to kill the prisoners so none of them could swim away and escape.

43.verse: But ·Julius, the officer, [the centurion] wanted to ·let Paul live [save Paul] and ·did not allow the soldiers to kill the prisoners [stopped them from their plan]. Instead he ordered everyone who could swim to jump into the water first and swim to land.

44.verse: The rest were to follow using wooden boards or pieces of the ship. And this is how all the people made it safely to land.

1.verse: Paul on the Island of Malta - When we ·were safe on land [reached safety], we learned that the island was called Malta [58 miles southwest of Sicily].

2.verse: The ·people who lived there [native people; barbarians; a term referring to non-Greek speakers] were very ·good [kind] to us. Because it was raining and very cold, they made a fire and welcomed all of us.

3.verse: Paul gathered a pile of ·sticks [brushwood] and was putting them on the fire when a ·poisonous snake [viper] came out because of the heat and ·bit [fastened itself to] him on the hand.

4.verse: The ·people living on the island [native people; 28:2] saw the ·snake [creature; animal] hanging from Paul’s hand and said to each other, “This man must be a murderer! He ·did not die in [escaped from] the sea, but Justice [Dikē; pronounced di-káy); the goddess of justice] ·does not want [has not allowed] him to live.”

5.verse: But Paul shook the ·snake [creature; animal] off into the fire and ·was not hurt [suffered no harm].

6.verse: ·The people [They] thought that Paul would swell up or fall down dead. They waited and watched him for a long time, but nothing ·bad [unusual] happened to him. So they changed their minds and said, “He is a god!”

7.verse: There ·were some fields [or was an estate] around there owned by Publius, ·an important man [or the chief official; governor] on the island. He ·welcomed [received] us into his home and ·was very good to us [provided generous hospitality; treated us as honored guests] for three days.

8.verse: Publius’ father was sick in bed with a fever and dysentery [a serious illness that includes cramping and severe diarrhea]. Paul went to him, prayed, and ·put [or laid] his hands on the man and healed him.

9.verse: After this, ·all the other [the rest of the] sick people on the island came to Paul, and he healed them, too.

10.verse: The people on the island gave us many honors. When we were ready to leave, they gave us the ·things [provisions] we needed. Paul Goes to Rome - After three months we got on a ship from Alexandria [27:6] that had stayed on the island during the winter. On the front of the ship was the sign of the ·twin gods [Castor and Pollux, the twin sons of Zeus; protectors of sailors].

11.verse: The people on the island gave us many honors. When we were ready to leave, they gave us the ·things [provisions] we needed. Paul Goes to Rome - After three months we got on a ship from Alexandria [27:6] that had stayed on the island during the winter. On the front of the ship was the sign of the ·twin gods [Castor and Pollux, the twin sons of Zeus; protectors of sailors].

12.verse: We ·stopped [put in] at Syracuse [a major city on the island of Sicily] for three days.

13.verse: From there we ·sailed to [set sail and arrived at] Rhegium [a port city on the Italian mainland across from Sicily]. The next day a wind began to blow from the south, and ·a day later [on the second day] we came to Puteoli [a bit further north on the southwestern coast of Italy].

14.verse: We found some ·believers [brothers (and sisters)] there who ·asked [invited] us to stay with them for ·a week [seven days]. ·Finally [And so in this way], we came to Rome.

15.verse: The ·believers [brothers (and sisters)] in Rome heard that we were there and came out as far as the ·Market [Forum] of Appius [about 40 miles from Rome] and the Three Inns [eight miles toward Rome from the Market of Appius] to meet us. When Paul saw them, he thanked God and ·was encouraged [took courage].

16.verse: Paul in Rome - When we arrived at Rome, Paul was allowed to live alone, with the soldier who guarded him.

17.verse: Three days later ·Paul [he] sent for the leaders of the ·Jewish community [Jews] there. When they came together, he said, “[Men,] Brothers, I have done nothing against our people or the customs of our ·ancestors [forefathers; fathers]. But I was ·arrested [made a prisoner] in Jerusalem and given ·to [into the hands of] the Romans.

18.verse: After they ·asked me many questions [examined me; tried my case], they wanted to let me go free because they could find no reason why I should be ·killed [given the death penalty].

19.verse: But the Jews there ·argued against that [objected], so I had to ·ask to come to Rome to have my trial before [appeal to] Caesar. But I have no ·charge [accusation] to bring against my own ·people [nation].

20.verse: That is why I wanted to see you and talk with you. I am bound with this chain because ·I believe in [of] the hope of Israel.”

21.verse: They ·answered [said to] Paul, “We have received no letters from Judea about you. None of our Jewish brothers who have come from there brought news or told us anything bad about you.

22.verse: But we ·want to hear [consider it worth hearing] your ideas, because we know that people everywhere are speaking against this ·religious group [sect].”

23.verse: Paul and the people ·chose [arranged; appointed] a day for a meeting and on that day ·many more of the Jews [a great number] met with Paul at the place he was staying. He spoke to them ·all day long [from morning until evening]. Using the law of Moses and the prophets’ writings [the whole Old Testament], he explained [by testifying/bearing witness about] the kingdom of God, and he tried to persuade them to believe these things about Jesus.

24.verse: Some ·believed [were persuaded by] what Paul said, but others ·did [were] not.

25.verse: So they ·argued [disagreed with each other] and began leaving after Paul said one more thing to them: “The Holy Spirit spoke the truth to your ·ancestors [fathers] through Isaiah the prophet, saying,

26.verse: ‘Go to this people and say: You will ·listen and listen [or certainly listen], but you will not understand. You will ·look and look [or certainly look], but you will not ·learn [perceive],

27.verse: because [the heart of] these people have become ·stubborn [dull]. They ·don’t hear with their ears [or hardly hear with their ears; are hard of hearing], and they have closed their eyes. Otherwise, they might see with their eyes and hear with their ears. They might really understand in their ·minds [hearts] and come back to me and ·be healed [I would heal them; Is. 6:9–10].’

28.verse: “[Therefore,] I want you to know that God has also sent his salvation to ·all nations [the Gentiles], and they will listen!”

29.verse: | ·After [or When] ·Paul [he] said this, the Jews left. They were arguing very much with each other.|

30.verse: Paul stayed two full years ·in his own rented house [or at his own expense] and welcomed all people who came to visit him.

31.verse: He ·boldly [confidently] ·preached about [proclaimed] the kingdom of God and taught about the Lord Jesus Christ, ·and no one stopped him [freely; without hindrance].
